moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 g6 3. c4: In my tournament experience I don't like playing any type of Colle/London setup against the King's Indian, as I usually end up with a position I don't like to be in, and I don't play any type of anti-indians with the dark bishop; Ergo my reason to play the Classical KID.
moves.3... Bg7 4. Nc3 d6 5. e4 O-O 6. Be2 e5 7: This move came a little shocking to me and I didn't know how to proceed.  Even at my stage I expect the player to make the moves he "needs" to make!  LOL!  What kind of chess player am I?  I thought I could play this game on auto-pilot.
moves.10. Bb2 f5 11. Ng5 Nf6 12. Bf3 h6 13. Ne: I don't know if this was the way to proceed the game.
moves.15... g5: ?!/!?/!  I don't which one to grade it but it sure shocked me?  Indeed I even panic some and decied I need to move the game in my direction even more.
moves.16. exf5: I don't if this was good.
moves.16... Nxf5 17. Ne4: I don't know what my plan was as this game is over a year old now.
moves.17... Nxe4 18. Bxe4 Qf6 19. b5: I was thinking along the lines of other games and I remember the common theme of White's wins is the attack on the Queen-side. lol
moves.19... Rac8: I don't know if he could have deflected his Knight on f5.
moves.21... Qxe6 22. Bxc6: Again, I am playing the game the way I want it to head towards.
moves.23. Qd5 Nxd5 24. Bxd5 Qxd5 25. cxd5 Rc2: !! I knew this started the end of my game.
moves.26. Rab1 Rfxf2 27. Ba3: What was I going to do know?
moves.27... Rfxg2+ 28. Kh1 Rgxh2+ 29. Kg1 Rcg2: I didn't know how to proceed. What else was there?
moves.33... Kxf8 34. Bxd6+ Kf7 35. Bxe5 Rhg2+: I would say, from move 38 or so, I continued to play, so I could view this young boy's technique with his rook play.
